NATIONAL ECONOMICS UNIVERSITY INSTITUTE OF ADVANCED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS | SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF VIETNAM Independence – Freedom – Happiness
COURSE SYLLABUS
(Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,           ,            , 2023)

- English Title: Object-oriented Programming       Code: CNTT1131E
- Level Of Education: Undergraduate
- Type Of Education: Full-Time
- Credits: 3
- Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
- Lecture: 20 hrs
- Presentation and Discussion: 5 hrs
- Exercise and discussion: 23 hrs
- Self-study: 99 hrs.
- Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1128; CNTT1116
- Faculty conducting the course: School of Information Technology and Digital Economics, Suite 1310, Building A1, National Economics University, 207 Giai Phong str., Hai Ba Trung dist., Ha Noi, Vietnam.
- Kind of the course:

Foundation | Foundation | Fundamental (x) | Fundamental (x)
Compulsory | Elective | Compulsory (x) | Elective

This course provides knowledge about: Basic concepts of object-oriented programming such as classes, objects, constructors, destructors, friend functions.... The characteristics of object-oriented programming methods such as encapsulation, inheritance, and abstraction. Methods of analysis and design of problems in an object-oriented approach; I/O stream operations and file operations. How to catch and handle exceptions. The content of the object-oriented programming method is described through the C++ programming language (Can also use the C# or Java programming language to illustrate)
The course also aims to practice thinking skills, the ability to self-learn the knowledge of object-oriented programming methods by working independently as well as in groups. Learners have the skills to build a real application using object-oriented programming methods.

[1] Nguyen Thanh Thuy, Object-oriented Programming, Publishing scientific and technical, 1999.
[2]. Pham Van At, C++ and Object-oriented Programming, Publishing scientific and technical, 2000.

[3] Pham Van At, Advanced Programming Technical, Publishing scientific and technical, 2000.
[4] Jim Keogh & Mario Giannini, Object-oriented Programming, 2004.

Table 4. Course goals
Goals | Goal Description | Program Learning Outcomes (PLO) | Proficiency scale
[1] | [2] | [3] | [4]
G1 | The module provides learners with knowledge of object-oriented programming methods, building programs in an object-oriented approach. | PLO 1.4.2, PLO 1.4.4 | 4
G2 | The course trains programming skills and thinking, practical skills in analysis, design and construction of dedicated functional modules. | PLO 2.1.1, PLO 2.2.1 | 3U
G3 | The course contributes to the development of the ability to work independently and in a team, to properly understand the responsibility for job performance and professional ethics. | PLO 3.1.1, PLO 3.1.2, PLO 3.2.3 | 3

Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)
Goal | CLO | Description | Capacity level
[1] | [2] | [3] | [4]
G1 | CLO1.1 | Understand object-oriented programming methods, compare advantages and disadvantages of object-oriented programming methods with procedural (traditional) programming methods. | 2
G1 | CLO1.2 | Distinguish the main features of object-oriented programming, class definition, and object declaration. | 3
G1 | CLO1.3 | Define inheritance and polymorphism to illustrate the hierarchical feature of object-oriented programming. | 3
G1 | CLO1.4 | Apply object-oriented programming methods to build programs to solve problems. | 4
G2 | CLO2.1 | Skilled in analyzing, designing and building custom functions according to object-oriented programming methods. | 3U
G2 | CLO2.2 | Have programming skills and thinking to solve problems using object-oriented programming methods. | 3U
G3 | CLO3.1 | Ability to self-study, self-study materials or work in groups to complete assigned lessons and assignments. | 3
G3 | CLO3.2 | Consciously organize class discipline, comply with classroom rules, have a spirit of cooperation and personal responsibility for the activities assigned by the lecturer. | 3

* Assessment methods:
- Grading: 10
- Average score of course is the total points of rubrics multiplied by the respective weight of each rubric.
